explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" or "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" or "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" or "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: No data available. However, PCBs whose physicochemical properties are very similar to those of PCTs have the flash points of 170-380degC (EHC 140 (1993)), and therefore the flash points of PCTs may exceed 93degC, which is "Not classified."

flammable_solids.rationale: PTCs had previously been used as fire-retardants (EHC 140 (1993)). Classified into Class 9 (UN#3151 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (liquid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#2315, liquid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (liquid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)), UN#3152 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (solid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#3432, solid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (solid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Considered non-pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures since the substance had previously been used as a fire-retardant (EHC 140 (1993). Classified into Class 9 (UN#3151 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (liquid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#2315, liquid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (liquid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Considered non-pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures since the substance had previously been used as a fire-retardant (EHC 140 (1993). Classified into Class 9 (UN#3152 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (solid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#3432, solid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (solid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

self_heating_substances.classification: Classification not possible (Liquid or solid with melting point of <= 140degC), Not classified (Melting point of >140degC)
self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid or solid substances with melting point of <=140degC are not available (test temperature: 140degC), whereas those with melting point of >140degC cannot be classified due to lack of data. Classified into Class 9 (UN#3151 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (liquid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#2315, liquid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (liquid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)), UN#3152 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (solid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#3432, solid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (solid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)) by the UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, which is "Not classified."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing chlorine (but not oxygen and fluorine), with the chlorine bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing chlorine (but not oxygen and fluorine), with the chlorine bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classified into Class 9 (UN#3151 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (liquid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#2315, liquid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (liquid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)), UN#3152 (Polyhalogenated Biphenyls (solid; excluding polychlorinated biphenyls (UN#3432, solid); those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list), or Polyhalogenated Terphenyls (solid; those with concentrations of not more than 50mg/kg are not included in the Dangerous Goods list)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the mouse LD50 (oral route) value of 2,100mg/kg (RTECS (2006)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is a liquid or solid according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (skin, liver)
aspiration_hazard.rationale:
Based on the evidence from animal studies including "loss of hair on the head, neck and back, facial swelling, swelling of eyelids and lips, and hepatocellular hypertrophy" (MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 4 (2005)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.
Note: Since the study on which assessment of the liver effects is based used the test material containing 5% PCB (ID 0199 (published): classified as Category 1 (skin, liver)) as a contaminant, the effects observed might potentially be attributable to PCB.
